articles.headline: Stepping In for a Parent With Alzheimer’s
articles.snippet: Children may have to handle mundane tasks like paying bills, or become immersed in a parent’s financial affairs.
articles.abstract: Children may have to handle mundane tasks like paying bills, or become immersed in a parent’s financial affairs.
articles.lead_paragraph: As my grandfather’s mind slipped away, first slowly, then quickly, as Alzheimer’s disease moved in, he tried to be reassuring. “I remember the important things,” he would tell us.

articles.headline: Antibiotics Research Subsidies Weighed by U.S.
articles.snippet: Government officials are considering financial incentives to spur the development of vitally needed antibiotics.
articles.abstract: Government officials are considering financial incentives to spur the development of vitally needed antibiotics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worried about an impending public health crisis, government officials are considering offering financial incentives to the pharmaceutical industry, like tax breaks and patent extensions, to spur the development of vitally needed antibiotics.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Defends Action in Face of Criticism
articles.snippet: In the face of objections from other countries, the Fed chief said a global recovery depended on the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: In the face of objections from other countries, the Fed chief said a global recovery depended on the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Friday defended the central bank’s decision to inject $600 billion into the American economy, in the face of objections from European and Asian officials about the weakening of the dollar that is likely to result from the action.

articles.headline: Unyielding, an Oligarch vs. Putin
articles.snippet: Mikhail Khodorkovsky has become, in the Putin era, a courageous dissident standing up to an authoritarian regime.
articles.abstract: Mikhail Khodorkovsky has become, in the Putin era, a courageous dissident standing up to an authoritarian regime.
articles.lead_paragraph: I wish I had enough space to reprint in its entirety Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky’s closing statement, as his latest sham trial in Russia came to an end earlier this week. I have never been so moved by the words of a businessman.

articles.headline: Shell Presses for Drilling in Arctic
articles.snippet: Eager to begin its stalled plan to drill in the Alaskan Arctic, the oil company is starting a lobbying campaign.
articles.abstract: Eager to begin its stalled plan to drill in the Alaskan Arctic, the oil company is starting a lobbying campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Eager to win approval for its stalled plan to drill for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, Royal Dutch Shell is beginning a public lobbying campaign, including national advertising, on Monday. As part of the effort, the giant oil company is promising to make unprecedented preparations to prevent the kind of disaster that polluted the Gulf of Mexico earlier this year.

articles.headline: Dividends From Fannie and Freddie Surpass Aid
articles.snippet: The two mortgage finance companies are still losing money, but their need for federal aid has tapered off.
articles.abstract: The two mortgage finance companies are still losing money, but their need for federal aid has tapered off.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The federal government made a profit of $1.1 billion in the third quarter on its huge bailout of the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, even as the two companies continued to lose money on bad loans.

articles.headline: As H.I.V. Babies Come of Age, Problems Linger
articles.snippet: Some H.I.V. babies now entering adulthood are struggling with the epidemic’s legacy.
articles.abstract: Some H.I.V. babies now entering adulthood are struggling with the epidemic’s legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARWICK, R.I. — “They’ve been telling me since age 3 that I would die,” Tom Cosgrove said quietly. “Then age 6, age 8, age 10.”

articles.headline: Olbermann of MSNBC Suspended Over Donations
articles.snippet: The indefinite suspension was a stark display of the clash between objectivity and opinion in television journalism.
articles.abstract: The indefinite suspension was a stark display of the clash between objectivity and opinion in television journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Keith Olbermann, the leading liberal voice on American television in the age of Obama, was suspended Friday after his employer, MSNBC, discovered he made campaign contributions to three Democrats last month.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Despite Losses, Nancy Pelosi Will Run for House Post
articles.snippet: The speaker’s decision to run for minority leader threatened to fracture a Democratic caucus reeling from election defeat.
articles.abstract: The speaker’s decision to run for minority leader threatened to fracture a Democratic caucus reeling from election defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Despite severe election losses that cost her party the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday that she would run to remain the leader of House Democrats even as some of her colleagues urged her to step aside.

articles.headline: Saudis Warned U.S. of Attack Before Parcel Bomb Plot
articles.snippet: Saudi intelligence officials warned that an Al Qaeda affiliate was planning an attack using aircraft three weeks before a plot to send parcel bombs was foiled, officials said.
articles.abstract: Saudi intelligence officials warned that an Al Qaeda affiliate was planning an attack using aircraft three weeks before a plot to send parcel bombs was foiled, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Saudi intelligence officials warned the United States in early October that Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen was planning a terrorist attack using one or more aircraft, three weeks before a plot to send parcel bombs on cargo planes was foiled at the last minute, American and European officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Scott Shane

articles.headline: While Warning About Fat, U.S. Pushes Cheese Sales
articles.snippet: When sales of Domino’s Pizza were lagging, a government agency stepped in with advice: more cheese. This is the same government that, for health reasons, is advising less cheese.
articles.abstract: When sales of Domino’s Pizza were lagging, a government agency stepped in with advice: more cheese. This is the same government that, for health reasons, is advising less cheese.
articles.lead_paragraph: Domino’s Pizza was hurting early last year. Domestic sales had fallen, and a survey of big pizza chain customers left the company tied for the worst tasting pies.

articles.headline: Alaska Writes a Senator Back Into Contention
articles.snippet: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska played many novel roles in her run as a write-in candidate. Yet she returned to an ordinary political platitude: the local rallying cry.
articles.abstract: Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska played many novel roles in her run as a write-in candidate. Yet she returned to an ordinary political platitude: the local rallying cry.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE  Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska played many novel roles in her historic run as a write-in candidate. She was the insurgent incumbent, the maverick moderate, the outsider from the establishment, the underdog boasting about her seniority.

articles.headline: He Saw Trouble Coming. Now He Sees It Going.
articles.snippet: Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics warned in 2005 that real estate would crash and a recession would ensue. Today he sees reasons for hope.
articles.abstract: Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics warned in 2005 that real estate would crash and a recession would ensue. Today he sees reasons for hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARE we finally coming out of the woods, economically speaking?

articles.headline: When a Rig Moves In Next Door
articles.snippet: In states accustomed to its risks, drilling for natural gas is seen as an economic lifeline. But in the Northeast, some residents fear the long-term environmental impact.
articles.abstract: In states accustomed to its risks, drilling for natural gas is seen as an economic lifeline. But in the Northeast, some residents fear the long-term environmental impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the sparsely populated pastures of De Soto Parish in Louisiana, the ability to extract gas from shale  which can involve a process known as fracking  has been welcomed as an economic windfall. Some residents call it a gift from God.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: Chasing Pirates: Inside Microsoft’s War Room
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s theft fight has implications beyond the bottom line in an industry that relies on intellectual property.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s theft fight has implications beyond the bottom line in an industry that relies on intellectual property.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS the sun rose over the mountains circling Los Reyes, a town in the Mexican state of Michoacán, one morning in March 2009, a caravan of more than 300 heavily armed law enforcement agents set out on a raid.

articles.headline: Taking On a Second Mortgage to Pay the Foreclosure Lawyer
articles.snippet: Some defense lawyers call the mortgages crass. Yet they solve a vexing issue: How can clients who are broke pay?
articles.abstract: Some defense lawyers call the mortgages crass. Yet they solve a vexing issue: How can clients who are broke pay?
articles.lead_paragraph: For some Florida residents, the price of getting out of foreclosure will include taking on a second mortgage  payable this time to their lawyers.

articles.headline: Obama Invokes Gandhi, Whose Ideal Eludes India
articles.snippet: Gandhi is revered in India, but his calls for personal austerity and nonviolence have proved antithetical to the goals of an aspiring economic and military power.
articles.abstract: Gandhi is revered in India, but his calls for personal austerity and nonviolence have proved antithetical to the goals of an aspiring economic and military power.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Not long after Barack Obama was elected president, the United States Embassy in India printed a postcard showing him sitting in his old Senate office beneath framed photographs of his political heroes: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Abraham Lincoln and the great Indian apostle of peace, democracy and nonviolent protest, Mohandas K. Gandhi.

articles.headline: Web Browsing Takes a Social Turn
articles.snippet: A new browser from RockMelt integrates sites like Twitter and Facebook and makes it simple to keep in touch with friends also logged in.
articles.abstract: A new browser from RockMelt integrates sites like Twitter and Facebook and makes it simple to keep in touch with friends also logged in.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Silicon Valley is awash in tales of the “PayPal Mafia,” the tight-knit group of PayPal alumni who have helped one another start and finance a crop of new companies.

articles.headline: Maneuver Over Copters Is Opposed
articles.snippet: An Air Force proposal to attach an order for helicopters to an old military contract without competitive bids is opposed.
articles.abstract: An Air Force proposal to attach an order for helicopters to an old military contract without competitive bids is opposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Air Force has taken a beating over its contract process in recent years. But if officials thought a new approach would avoid controversy, they have been disappointed.

articles.headline: Olbermann, Impartiality and MSNBC
articles.snippet: If MSNBC were really worried about coming off as impartial, don’t you think it would have chosen somebody besides Mr. Olbermann to anchor its election coverage?
articles.abstract: If MSNBC were really worried about coming off as impartial, don’t you think it would have chosen somebody besides Mr. Olbermann to anchor its election coverage?
articles.lead_paragraph: MSNBC, worried that its reputation as a fair broker of the news hung in the balance, sent Keith Olbermann to the woodshed on Friday for an unpaid suspension because he had donated $7,200 to some of the Democratic politicians he had championed on his hit show “Countdown.”

articles.headline: Irish Debt Woes Revive Concern About Europe
articles.snippet: Recent jitters in the bond market are a forceful reminder that investors remain wary of European sovereign debt.
articles.abstract: Recent jitters in the bond market are a forceful reminder that investors remain wary of European sovereign debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  When interest rates soared last week on Irish government bonds, it served as a grim warning to other indebted nations of how difficult and even politically ruinous it could be to roll back decades of public sector largess.

articles.headline: For Afghan Wives, a Desperate, Fiery Way Out
articles.snippet: Many Afghan women set themselves on fire to escape lives of servitude and abuse.
articles.abstract: Many Afghan women set themselves on fire to escape lives of servitude and abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan  Even the poorest families in Afghanistan have matches and cooking fuel. The combination usually sustains life. But it also can be the makings of a horrifying escape: from poverty, from forced marriages, from the abuse and despondency that can be the fate of Afghan women.

articles.headline: Friedman Casts Shadow as Economists Meet
articles.snippet: A weekend gathering of top Fed officials and economists took on the air of an awkward family reunion, with rivalries for the affections of an ancestor, Milton Friedman.
articles.abstract: A weekend gathering of top Fed officials and economists took on the air of an awkward family reunion, with rivalries for the affections of an ancestor, Milton Friedman.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  The Federal Reserve is portraying its $600 billion plan to prop up the economic recovery as a difficult but needed step to promote growth by lifting stock prices and making long-term borrowing even cheaper.

articles.headline: With Book, Bush Is Back in Spotlight
articles.snippet: George W. Bush will end a self-imposed silence about his presidency in an NBC special with Matt Lauer on Monday.
articles.abstract: George W. Bush will end a self-imposed silence about his presidency in an NBC special with Matt Lauer on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: George W. Bush will end a self-imposed silence about his presidency in an NBC prime-time special on Monday, the eve of the release of his memoir, “Decision Points.” That the interviewer will be Matt Lauer, the co-host of the “Today” show, reveals calculations by Mr. Bush and his advisers, as well as a campaign by NBC.

articles.headline: Now in Power, G.O.P. Vows Cuts in State Budgets
articles.snippet: States face huge deficits, and incoming Republican leaders are promising to respond with an array of cuts.
articles.abstract: States face huge deficits, and incoming Republican leaders are promising to respond with an array of cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans who have taken over state capitols across the country are promising to respond to crippling budget deficits with an array of cuts, among them proposals to reduce public workers’ benefits in Wisconsin, scale back social services in Maine and sell off state liquor stores in Pennsylvania, endangering the jobs of thousands of state workers.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Michael Luo

articles.headline: D.E.A. Deployed Mumbai Plotter Despite Warning
articles.snippet: The U.S. sent an informant to Pakistan after the 9/11 attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical groups.
articles.abstract: The U.S. sent an informant to Pakistan after the 9/11 attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American authorities sent David C. Headley, a small-time drug dealer and sometime informant, to work for them in Pakistan months after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical Islamic groups, according to court records and interviews. Not long after Mr. Headley arrived there, he began training with terrorists, eventually playing a key role in the 2008 attacks that left 164 people dead in Mumbai.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson, Eric Schmitt and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Cost of Green Power Makes Projects Tougher Sell
articles.snippet: Clean energy is still a goal, but falling prices for conventional energy make the competition tighter.
articles.abstract: Clean energy is still a goal, but falling prices for conventional energy make the competition tighter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Polsky’s wind farm company was doing so well in 2008 that banks were happy to lend millions for his effort to light up America with clean electricity.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: Bad News for Liberals May Be Good News for a Liberal Magazine
articles.snippet: History hints that opposition in the Capitol could help the bottom line at The Nation.
articles.abstract: History hints that opposition in the Capitol could help the bottom line at The Nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Other than perhaps the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee, there were few places as despondent on election night as the Manhattan offices of The Nation, the 146-year-old journal of fiery leftist opinion.

articles.headline: Countering China, Obama Backs India for U.N. Council
articles.snippet: Analysts say that China has been cool to the idea of permanent membership on the U.N. Security Council for rival Asian powers.
articles.abstract: Analysts say that China has been cool to the idea of permanent membership on the U.N. Security Council for rival Asian powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  By endorsing India for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, President Obama on Monday signaled the United States’ intention to create a deeper partnership of the world’s two largest democracies that would expand commercial ties and check the influence of an increasingly assertive China.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jim Yardley
